Point Number Two. I detect, now and then, and incipient ’’Ivory Tower” point of
view in NAEB thinking. And this is dangerous.
So often we say, ’’Good educational material can stand on its own feet. On its
own merits, it will make good radio listening.” We say this too often, I think
categorically and complacently.
But how often do we present this good educational material without any attempt to
relate it to the listener’s world and show him how it can have meaning for him in
terms of his everyday living?
We agreed, at Allerton House, that educational broadcasting, like education itself,
cannot in a democracy be the prerogative of a privileged fewr. I say that, for
instance, when we go on the air cold with a reading of Plato’s Republic, without
some regard for the man who only knows Plato as a name out of ancient Greek history,
we are doing Plato a great dis-ser’-‘ oe. Putting it figuratively, we have not even
done him the courtesy of introducing him properly to a potential friend. And the
same holds true for a broadcast in the field of child development or political geog¬
raphy or modern art.
Some of you, I’m sure have read Alburey Castell’s fine speech at the NAEB Region VI
meeting in Eugene earlier this month. It came to us several days ago in the latest
NAEB Newsletter mailing, and I can't recommend it highly enough. A great scholar,
formerly at Minnesota, now at uregon, who is probably one of the most effective
educational broadcasters in the business. In his Eugene speech, Dr. Castell spoke
directly to all scholars and professors who might be contemplating a radio talk or
a series of radio lectures. He said, among many other valuable things: "Presuppose
as close to nothing as you can. Supply what your listener has to have to follow
you. This may cramp your style; but put up with the cramps, if you want listeners.
This is not to say that listeners are ignorant: they aren’t. But they don't have
your specialized knowledge, and they haven’t given as much thought to your topic
as you have. Your language is esoteric. Your information is esoteric. Your pat¬
tern. of thought is esoteric. These are obstacles to be overcome.”
How often are we conscious of this? And how often, even if we ourselves are con¬
scious of it, do we make any effort to get it across to the obliging academic ex¬
pert who is taking the time to do a broadcast or a series for us? Granted, he is
probably donating his services for free, and we don't like to impose on him. But
this is ho imposition. Actually, we're not doing right by him or his material, if
we don't make him aware of the special demands of educational broadcasting. After
all, he wants to do an effective job, and he looks to us to help him how to do it.
Now, all of us recognize our obligation to serve the needs of the minority audiences
•—and in particular, those limited groups who have already had considerable formal
education. But let's again be mindful, as we were at Allerton House, of the danger
that still exists-namely that these special services can be given too great empha¬
sis.
So there you have a few predictions and recommendations for the future of education¬
al broadcasting.
One-radio is here to stay and will continue to command a large audience.
Two-we are seeing a very definite trend toward more adult offerings on the
networks, indicating their discovery that a sizable segment of the Amer¬
ican people are not, as they believed, a bunch of 12-year-olds. An
increased interest, generally, in educational and cultural material. A
big opportunity for all of us to capture an even greater audience.
